data.title: Support VIM style navigation in trees like the explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: Windows 10

I like Visual Studio Code and am thinking about replacing VIM. But one thing is still missing that is very important for me: navigating in the explorer with NERDTree keybindings. Is there a plan to make the keybindings in the explorer configurable? This would be great!

Thanks!

data.title: It's not possible to use `(` for accepting completion suggestions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is really a dupe of #11016 but that's been closed but the provided solution doesn't work.

If you do this (as provided as an example):

``` text
"key": ".",
"command": "^acceptSelectedSuggestion",
"when": "editorTextFocus && suggestWidgetVisible && editorLangId == 'typescript' && suggestionSupportsAcceptOnKey"
```

then pressing `.` will automatically commit the selected item in the completion. However, if you try to use `(` instead of `.` then it doesn't work.

Probably related, the [Accepted Keys](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/keybindings#_accepted-keys) section of the docs don't list `(` and `)` as valid keys.

I'm not sure whether there's a deliberate reason for this but it seems strange; Visual Studio commits on `(` so it's something that many developers are used to; it would be good to support here.

(Apologies if I shouldn't have created a new case, but I was told not to comment on closed cases, so I'm a little unsure of what to do in a case like this - if someone can clarify I can make sure to do the preferred thing in future!).

data.title: VSCode and Webpack module casing issue
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  1.4.0
- OS Version:
  Windows 10
  Node: 6.3.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VScode
2. Open terminal 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3470892/18230541/a2ef75a2-7296-11e6-80bf-564cf948e786.png)

Running webpack command with drive letter as lowercase c, causing warning on javascript modules:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3470892/18230564/016974de-7297-11e6-8c09-db966a853bce.png)

Same is the case when opening terminal using Ctrl + Shift + C opens command prompt with drive letter as lowercase and running webpack command. 

However when running command prompt from windows programs, which opens it with uppercase driver letter "**C**" when webpack doesn't show any warning. 

So, is there a way to force VScode to open terminal with uppercase C drive which will fix the webpack warnings?

data.title: Feature Request: Add Task Tags such as TODO, NOTE, HACK, FIXME, etc
data.body:
Couldn't find any documentation on this or any good extensions. Would be amazing if we could have task tags, something that could be user defined/customizable inside settings.json

Similar to:

```
editor.taskTags: [
    { name: "TODO", color: "#00FF00" },
    { name: "BUG", color: "#FF0000" },
    { name: "NOTE", color: "#0000FF" }
]
```

``` javascript
// TODO: Find out why click event is undefined...
event.target.click();
```

The TODO comment would then be highlighted in the color chosen in the settings file, for this example "Green".

data.title: Feature Request: Remove extension command registeration from package.json
data.body:
Currently, you register an extension command by defining it in the `package.json` and also registering it within your code.

My request is to remove commands from needing to be defined in `package.json` contributions and make them definable and registerable only within your code.

This would open up the door for new functionality and flexibility and dynamic extension command registrations. For example being able to register a command on the fly only for specific languages.

The other part of this request is to be able to unregister commands so that they do not show up in the command palette anymore. I don't see a way in the API to unregister commands.

Again, a use case for this would be unregistering a command that is language specific. For example if you have a command you want available only for the HTML language. The way you would accomplish this:
1. Make your extension activate on the `"onLanguage:html"` activationEvent.
2. Register your extension command in your code so now its available for HTML language
3. When you switch to a different language, your extension deactivates, you code could deregister the command in you code, so now its no longer available for other extensions

So now you have an extension command that is limited only to a certain language. This is just a simple example but I imagine there are many other use cases that would come from being able to dynamically register/deregister commands on the fly without needed them to be hardcoded in `package.json`.

data.title: Javascript Intellisense not working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

I followed all the instructions on the Intellisense for JS setup page. I have a project folder which contains the following jsconfig.json file:
`{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "ES5"
    },
    "exclude": [
        "node_modules"
    ]
}`

Also installed typings and dt~node (with --global) using it in my project directory.
Now when I try to edit a js file in my project folder, IntelliSense does not work, not even simple autocomplete. If I try to trigger it using Ctrl + Space, a box with text "Loading..." appears and stays like that forever. 
When I edit files outside my project directory individually, autocomplete works fine. (tried both HTML and JS files).

I also set the tssserver output option to verbose and checked the output window. This is the output after a few attempts at using Intellisense:

data.title: Write access problems are not handled clean
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Debian stable 64 bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file which is only readable for this user
2. Change something and try to save. Bam! A warning is shown:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2410353/18227121/294116a6-721a-11e6-98c2-97afe8f695fb.png)
3. Click on "retry" and visual studio is happy again, the dialog was closed. But the file is not saved!

clicking "retry" triggers the same warning in the console again:
`messageService.ts:119 Fehler beim Speichern von "admin_int.php": Systemfehler (EACCES: permission denied, open '/var/www/XXXX`

data.title: Keybindings SuggestWidgetFocus /or/ contextual Enter to select
data.body:
- VSCode Version: I'm on 1.4 but I would suppose any
- OS Version: Win 10, OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Turn on _QuickSuggestions_
2. Try with vs. without `acceptSelectedSuggestionOnEnter`

To preface... I had to turn off `acceptSelectedSuggestionOnEnter` (by setting `"editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": false,` in my settings.json file) because my fingers are trained to type enter regardless of what is on the screen, apparently they figure the computer is reading my mind, or some such (yep personifying fingers). Anyways, Sometimes I would hit enter because I wanted to use the suggested option, sometimes I wanted a new line and to ignore the option. IDEALLY my behavior is to mouse down and press enter.
# `"editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": false`
- [tab]
- [down] .... => [tab]
- [down] ..... => [up]...-1 => [tab]
# `"editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": true`
- [enter]
- [ideal]
- [down] .... => [tab]
- [down] .... => [enter]
- [down] ..... => [up]...-1 => [tab]
- [down] ..... => [up]...-1 => [enter]
# **IDEAL**
- [tab](rather - as it is now ,where it is configurable via `keybindings.json`)
- [down] .... => [tab]
- [down] .... => [enter]
- [down] ..... => [up]...-1 => [tab]
- [down] ..... => [up]...-1 => [enter]

I tried doing this via `keybindings.json` using:

``` json
{
    "key": "down enter",
    "command": "acceptSelectedSuggestion",
    "when": "editorTextFocus && suggestWidgetVisible"
}
```

But that only works for the first entry, afterwards it is pointless and it ruins any other downwards movement. Without a way to know that I am presently in the context or _focus_ of the suggestion dropdown, there is no way for me to know that **Enter** is a valid submission key.  Ideally if there was a `SuggestWidgetFocus` I could do this with a simple

``` json
{
    "key": "enter",
    "command": "acceptSelectedSuggestion",
    "when": "SuggestWidgetFocus"
}
```

or maybe if necessary?

``` json
{
    "key": "down",
    "command": "SuggestWidgetFocus",
    "when": "suggestWidgetVisible"
},{
    "key": "enter",
    "command": "acceptSelectedSuggestion",
    "when": "SuggestWidgetFocus"
}
```

To me this would be useful. If others think so - and the workload is not incredible to do, I would GREATLY appreciate this , as always!  Thank you!

data.title: window.reopenFolders: "none" not working in 1.4.0
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add to user settings (settings.json):  "window.reopenFolders": "none" 
2. Close VSCode.
3. Change directory to a project. Open VSCode with $ code .
4. It always opens with files previously opened for that project (including those in child folders)
5. Opening VS Code from Launcher opens VS Code without any files open. This issue seems to be caused by opening VS Code with "code ." in a project top-level folder.

data.title: Add 'Go to Symbol' to the 'Go' menu
data.body:
The 'Go' menu currently includes `Go to Symbol...` but it doesn't include `Go to any symbol by name` and we should add it. 

To do so we should rename `Go>Go to Symbol` to `Go>Go to Symbol in File` and then add `Go>Go to Symbol in Workspace`

data.title: Added new command to switch between windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Adds support to switch between windows.

> Switch Window

shows current opened windows in the quick open dialog. Then selecting one shows the window.

It is very needed while making service with TypeScript on the Micro Service Architecture.
